emergencies.title: Heart Attack
emergencies.description: A heart attack occurs when blood flow to part of the heart is blocked, causing damage to heart muscle.
dos: Call emergency services immediately (e.g., 112/108 in India).
Help the person sit down, rest, and stay calm.
Loosen any tight clothing.
Give one adult aspirin (300mg) to chew slowly, ONLY if not allergic and instructed by emergency services.
Be prepared to perform CPR if the person becomes unconscious and stops breathing.
donts: Do not leave the person alone, except to call for help if necessary.
Do not let the person deny symptoms or delay calling for help.
Do not give the person anything to eat or drink unless advised.
Do not allow the person to walk around.
Do not administer nitroglycerin unless it's prescribed to the person and you're instructed to.

questions.text: On a scale of 1 to 10, how severe is the chest pain/discomfort?
How would you describe the chest feeling?
Does the pain radiate to the arms, neck, jaw, or back?
Are there other symptoms like shortness of breath, nausea, sweating, or dizziness?
Does the person have a known history of heart problems?

emergencies.title: Stroke
emergencies.description: A stroke occurs when blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen.
dos: Call emergency services immediately. Time is critical!
Note the exact time the first symptoms appeared.
Keep the person comfortable and safe from falls.
If unconscious and breathing, place them in the recovery position (on their side).
Reassure the person while waiting for help.
donts: Do not give the person anything to eat or drink.
Do not give any medication (especially aspirin, as some strokes are caused by bleeding).
Do not delay calling for help, even if symptoms seem to improve.
Do not let the person fall asleep if they seem drowsy.
Do not assume the person is just confused or intoxicated.

questions.text: Ask the person to smile. Does one side of the face droop?
Ask the person to raise both arms. Does one arm drift downward or seem weak?
Ask the person to repeat a simple phrase (e.g., 'The sky is blue'). Is speech slurred or strange?
When did the first symptom appear? (Estimate if unsure)
Did the person experience a sudden, severe headache before other symptoms?

emergencies.title: Severe Bleeding
emergencies.description: Significant blood loss that is difficult to control and can be life-threatening.
dos: Call emergency services immediately.
Apply firm, direct pressure to the wound using a clean cloth or hands (use gloves if possible).
If possible, elevate the bleeding part above the level of the heart.
Maintain pressure until help arrives.
Keep the person warm and lying down if possible to prevent shock.
donts: Do not remove gauze or pads if they become soaked with blood; apply more on top.
Do not remove large or deeply embedded objects from the wound.
Do not apply a tourniquet unless trained and it's a life-threatening limb bleed.
Do not wash a severely bleeding wound.
Do not give the person anything to eat or drink.

questions.text: Where is the bleeding coming from?
Is the blood spurting (arterial) or flowing steadily (venous)?
Is direct pressure currently being applied to the wound?
Is there an object stuck in the wound?
Is the person conscious and alert?

emergencies.title: Unconscious Person
emergencies.description: An unconscious person is unable to respond to stimuli and requires immediate assessment and emergency care.
dos: Check for danger to yourself and the casualty.
Check for response (shout name, gently shake shoulders).
Shout for help and call emergency services immediately.
Open the airway (head-tilt/chin-lift) and check for normal breathing (look, listen, feel for up to 10 seconds).
If breathing normally, place in the recovery position. If not breathing normally, start CPR.
donts: Do not assume the person is just sleeping.
Do not put anything in their mouth (risk of choking).
Do not splash water on their face.
Do not move them unless they are in immediate danger.
Do not leave the person alone once emergency services are called.

questions.text: After opening the airway, is the person breathing normally (more than occasional gasps)?
Did you witness what caused the person to become unconscious (e.g., fall, seizure, other)?
Are there any obvious signs of severe injury (e.g., major bleeding, deformity)?
How long has the person been unconscious? (Estimate)
Is the immediate environment safe (e.g., no traffic, fire, fumes)?

emergencies.title: Poisoning
emergencies.description: Poisoning occurs when a harmful substance is ingested, inhaled, injected, or absorbed through the skin.
dos: Call emergency services or poison control immediately. Have substance information ready.
If the person is unconscious or having trouble breathing, call emergency services first.
Try to identify the poison (container, substance).
Follow dispatcher/poison control instructions precisely.
If safe, remove contaminated clothing and rinse skin/eyes with water if exposed.
donts: Do not induce vomiting unless specifically told to by poison control or emergency services.
Do not give activated charcoal unless instructed.
Do not give anything by mouth (milk, water) unless instructed.
Do not wait for symptoms to appear if poisoning is suspected.
Do not try to neutralize acids or alkalis with other substances.

questions.text: What type of substance was involved (e.g., medication, chemical, plant)?
How was the person exposed?
Is the person conscious and alert?
Approximately when did the exposure happen?
questions.description: e.g., 10 minutes ago, 1 hour ago, Unknown

questions.text: Are there any obvious symptoms (e.g., vomiting, burns, drowsiness, difficulty breathing)?

emergencies.title: Severe Burns
emergencies.description: Burns involving deep layers of skin, large areas, or sensitive locations (face, hands, genitals, joints).
dos: Call emergency services immediately.
Ensure the source of the burn is stopped and the area is safe.
Cool the burn with cool (not cold) running water for at least 10-20 minutes.
Cover the burn loosely with sterile, non-stick dressing or clean plastic wrap.
Keep the person warm.
donts: Do not apply ice, butter, creams, or ointments to severe burns.
Do not break blisters.
Do not remove clothing that is stuck to the burn.
Do not immerse large severe burns in cold water (risk of hypothermia).
Do not delay calling for help.

questions.text: What caused the burn?
Roughly how large is the burned area (e.g., size of person's palm, larger)?
What does the burned skin look like?

options.text: White, leathery, charred, possibly numb (Full thickness)

questions.text: Is the burn on the face, hands, feet, genitals, or over a major joint?
Was the person in a fire or enclosed space? Any signs of breathing difficulty?

emergencies.title: Choking
emergencies.description: Choking occurs when an object becomes lodged in the throat or windpipe, blocking airflow.
dos: Ask 'Are you choking?'. If they can speak or cough strongly, encourage coughing.
If they cannot speak, cough, or breathe, stand behind them and give 5 sharp back blows between the shoulder blades.
If back blows fail, perform 5 abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver).
Alternate 5 back blows and 5 abdominal thrusts.
If they become unconscious, call emergency services immediately and start CPR, checking the mouth for obstructions before rescue breaths.
donts: Do not panic; act quickly.
Do not put your fingers in their mouth unless you can clearly see and easily remove the object (risk of pushing it further).
Do not perform abdominal thrusts if the person can cough effectively.
Do not give water or food.
Do not stop trying until help arrives or the obstruction is cleared / person starts breathing.

questions.text: Can the person cough forcefully or speak?
Is the person currently conscious?
Is the person an adult, child, or infant?
Do you know what they might be choking on (food, small object)?
Is the person's face or lips turning blue?

emergencies.title: Severe Allergic Reaction
emergencies.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) that can occur rapidly.
dos: Call emergency services immediately.
Administer an epinephrine auto-injector (e.g., EpiPen) immediately if available and prescribed.
Help the person lie down flat. Elevate legs unless breathing is difficult.
If breathing is difficult, help them sit up.
Keep them warm.
donts: Do not wait to see if symptoms improve before calling help or using epinephrine.
Do not give anything by mouth if they have difficulty swallowing or breathing.
Do not assume a previous mild reaction means this one will be mild.
Do not hesitate to give a second epinephrine dose after 5-15 minutes if symptoms persist/return and help hasn't arrived.
Do not let the person stand up or walk suddenly.

questions.text: Is there difficulty breathing, wheezing, or throat tightness?
Is there swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat?
Does the person have an epinephrine auto-injector (EpiPen)?
If yes, has it been administered?
Are there skin symptoms like widespread hives, rash, or flushing?
Are there other symptoms like dizziness, collapse, vomiting, or abdominal pain?

emergencies.title: Head Injury
emergencies.description: Injury to the scalp, skull, or brain. Can range from mild bumps to severe traumatic brain injuries.
dos: Call emergency services for any loss of consciousness, severe headache, vomiting, seizure, or confusion.
Keep the person still, especially the head and neck if spinal injury is suspected.
Apply a cold compress to bumps or bruises.
Control any scalp bleeding with direct pressure.
Monitor level of consciousness and breathing.
donts: Do not move the person if a neck or spine injury is possible, unless they are in immediate danger.
Do not shake someone who has had a head injury.
Do not clean a deep head wound.
Do not remove any object penetrating the skull.
Do not give medication (like aspirin) without medical advice.

questions.text: Did the person lose consciousness, even briefly?
Is there a headache? If so, how severe (1-10)?
Has the person vomited since the injury?
Is the person confused, drowsy, or unable to remember the event?
Did the person have a seizure after the injury?

emergencies.title: Seizure
emergencies.description: Sudden, uncontrolled electrical disturbance in the brain, causing changes in behavior, movements, or consciousness.
dos: Protect the person from injury: ease them to the floor, clear the area of hard/sharp objects.
Place something soft under their head.
Turn them gently onto one side (recovery position) once shaking stops, to help breathing.
Time the seizure.
Stay with them and speak calmly until they are fully recovered.
donts: Do not try to restrain the person or hold them down.
Do not put anything in their mouth.
Do not give mouth-to-mouth resuscitation (they usually start breathing again on their own).
Do not offer food or drink until fully alert.
Do not assume they are okay immediately after the seizure stops; confusion is common.

questions.text: How long did the seizure last (in minutes)?
Is this the person's first known seizure?
Did the person sustain any injury during the seizure?
Has the person had more than one seizure without recovering in between?
How is the person now (after the shaking stopped)?

emergencies.title: Minor Burns
emergencies.description: Superficial burns (like sunburn) or small partial-thickness burns (blisters) affecting a limited area.
dos: Cool the burn under cool (not cold) running water for 10-20 minutes.
Remove jewelry or tight items from the burned area gently and quickly.
Cover the burn loosely with a sterile non-stick dressing or clean plastic wrap.
Take over-the-counter pain relievers if needed.
Keep the area clean.
donts: Do not use ice or iced water (can cause more damage).
Do not apply butter, oils, creams, or ointments (can trap heat and increase infection risk).
Do not break blisters (increases infection risk).
Do not use fluffy cotton wool dressing (can stick to burn).
Do not underestimate burns on children or the elderly; seek advice if unsure.

questions.text: How large is the burned area?
Are there blisters forming on the burn?
Is the burn on the face, hands, feet, genitals, or over a joint?
How much pain is the person experiencing (1-10)?
What caused the burn (e.g., hot water, sun, surface)?

emergencies.title: Heat Exhaustion
emergencies.description: Body overheating due to prolonged exposure to high temperatures or physical exertion, often with dehydration.
dos: Move the person to a cooler place, preferably shaded or air-conditioned.
Loosen or remove excess clothing.
Offer sips of cool water or sports drinks (if conscious and able to swallow).
Cool the skin with cool water (spray, sponge bath, wet cloths).
Monitor symptoms; seek medical help if they worsen or don't improve within an hour, or if heatstroke is suspected.
donts: Do not give drinks containing caffeine or alcohol.
Do not rely solely on fans; evaporative cooling (wet skin) is more effective.
Do not underestimate symptoms; heat exhaustion can quickly become heatstroke.
Do not rush the person back into strenuous activity.
Do not give salt tablets.

questions.text: Which symptoms are present?
What does the person's skin feel like?
Is the person alert and oriented, or confused/irritable?
Was the person engaged in strenuous activity in the heat?
After moving to cool area and drinking fluids, are symptoms improving?

emergencies.title: Frostbite
emergencies.description: Injury caused by freezing of the skin and underlying tissues. Most common on fingers, toes, nose, ears, cheeks, and chin.
dos: Move the person to a warmer place as soon as possible.
Remove wet clothing and gently cover the area with dry, sterile dressings.
Warm the affected area gradually using body heat (e.g., underarms) or warm water (NOT hot).
Offer warm, non-alcoholic drinks.
Seek medical attention, especially if skin is hard, numb, or blisters develop.
donts: Do not rub the frostbitten area (can cause more tissue damage).
Do not use direct heat like heating pads, fires, or radiators (can burn numb skin).
Do not break blisters if they form.
Do not re-freeze the area once thawed.
Do not give alcohol or allow smoking (can impair circulation).

questions.text: Which body parts are affected?
What does the affected skin look/feel like?

options.text: Hard, numb, possibly blistering or blackening

questions.text: Has rewarming been attempted?
Does the person feel pain or numbness in the area?
How long was the person exposed to the cold?

emergencies.title: Sprain or Strain
emergencies.description: Sprain: Stretching or tearing of ligaments. Strain: Stretching or tearing of muscle or tendon.
dos: Follow R.I.C.E: Rest, Ice (20 mins on/off), Compression (bandage), Elevation.
Use cold packs wrapped in a thin towel.
Support the injured area (sling, crutches if needed).
Take over-the-counter pain relievers if necessary.
Seek medical advice if pain is severe, unable to bear weight, or doesn't improve.
donts: Do not apply heat immediately after the injury.
Do not bear weight on a severely injured limb.
Do not ignore persistent pain or swelling.
Avoid tight compression that cuts off circulation.
Do not return to activity too soon.

questions.text: Which joint or muscle is injured?
Can the person put weight on the injured limb?
Is there significant swelling or bruising?
Did the person hear or feel a 'pop' at the time of injury?
Rate the pain level (1-10)

emergencies.title: Snake Bite
emergencies.description: A bite from a snake, which may or may not be venomous. Requires prompt attention.
dos: Call emergency services immediately.
Keep the person calm and still.
Position the bite area below the level of the heart if possible.
Remove tight clothing or jewelry near the bite.
Try to remember the snake's appearance if seen safely.
donts: Do not apply a tourniquet.
Do not cut the wound or attempt to suck out venom.
Do not apply ice or heat to the bite.
Do not give alcohol or caffeine.
Do not let the person walk around; keep them as still as possible.

questions.text: Was the snake seen? Can you describe it (color, pattern, head shape)?
Where on the body is the bite located?
What symptoms are present near the bite or elsewhere?
How long ago did the bite occur?
Does the person have any known allergies?

emergencies.title: Eye Injury
emergencies.description: Injury to the eye, ranging from scratches and foreign objects to chemical splashes or impact trauma.
dos: For chemical splashes, flush the eye immediately with clean water for 15-20 minutes.
For small particles (dust, eyelash), try blinking or gently flushing with water.
For cuts or embedded objects, cover the eye loosely with a sterile pad or eye shield/cup.
Seek immediate medical attention for significant pain, vision changes, chemicals, cuts, or embedded objects.
Keep the person calm.
donts: Do not rub the eye.
Do not try to remove an embedded object.
Do not apply pressure to the injured eye.
Do not put medication or ointments in the eye unless prescribed.
Do not delay seeking medical help for serious eye injuries.

questions.text: What type of injury occurred?
Is there any change in vision (blurriness, double vision, loss of vision)?
Rate the pain level (1-10)
Is there any visible bleeding from the eye itself?
Is an object currently stuck in the eye?
